conclusion: Analyzing motion with decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds using v-t graph
Velocity is on the y-axis in m/s and time is on the x-axis in seconds
Velocity increases to v = 20 m/s at t = 1s
From t = 1s to t = 2s, velocity decreases from 20 m/s to about 10 m/s
From t = 2s to t = 3s, velocity decreases from 10 m/s to 0 m/s
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the v-t graph
From 0 to 1s: The slope is positive and appears constant, indicating constant positive acceleration
From 1 to 2s: The slope is negative, and the curve appears concave upward, indicating decreasing magnitude of acceleration
From 2 to 3s: The slope is negative and appears constant, indicating constant negative acceleration
During the 1-2 second interval, the curve is not a straight line, indicating non-constant acceleration
The slope becomes less steep as time increases from 1s to 2s, indicating decreasing magnitude of acceleration
Linear motion refers to motion along a straight line
Gradually decreasing acceleration means acceleration is becoming less negative over time
The slope between 1-2s becomes less steep, indicating decreasing magnitude of negative acceleration
Yes, it is correct to say the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds
